page.title: 10Framlingham's lost hedgerows
page.content: Apart from the area around the Mere(p11 there is much less wildlife even than 30 years ago. Farmers have amalgamated fields by taking out hedgerows and filling in the ditches. The loss in nesting sites has affected the bird and animal populations. Sprays have reduced the numbers of wild flowers, particularly the patches of stinging nettles which are the homes of many butterflies. Nevertheless hedge parsley(called sheep parsley in Suffolk), adorns the sides of country lanes in May, and many other traditional plants continue to flourish away from sprayed areas. The wild primrose is much admired by visitors. Each year flocks of migratory swallows, swifts and house-martins join the resident bird population. A farm in the east of our surveyed area has won a conservation award planting new trees.
